claim.statement: agricultural yields are systematically higher for low-caste households residing in villages dominated by lower castes (BACs), in terms of total land ownership, compared to villages dominated by upper castes.
claim.hypothesis: H*: Among low-caste households, residing in villages dominated by lower castes is associated with greater agricultural income compared to residing in villages dominated by upper castes.

method.description: The study relied on village-level variation in caste dominance in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar. By collecting data on village dominance and comparing it to household agricultural outcomes.
steps: Collect data from surveys conducted in increments across households in villages predominately occupied by either low or upper-caste groups.
Analyze village attributes related to land ownership and public infrastructure against household agricultural metrics.
Employ econometric models to estimate the effects of village caste dominance on household agricultural incomes, incorporating control variables.

results.summary: Low-caste households' agricultural incomes were significantly higher when residing in villages dominated by their caste compared to upper-caste dominated locations.
